text:
Learning Objectives
By the end of this session, you will be able to:

Derive the kinematic equations for constant acceleration using integral calculus.
Use the integral formulation of kinematic equations in analyzing motion where acceleration is not constant.
Find the functional form of velocity versus time given the acceleration function.
Find the functional form of position versus time given the velocity function.


Our learning objectives reflect this shift. We’ll revisit the derivations of constant acceleration equations using integration, but more importantly, we’ll extend this method to handle variable acceleration. This means learning how to integrate an acceleration function to get velocity, and then integrating the velocity function to get position.

title: Physics
text:
Calculus in Kinematics: A Recap
Recall the fundamental relationships between position, velocity, and acceleration using derivatives:

Velocity is the time derivative of position: \[ v(t) = \frac{dx(t)}{dt} \]
Acceleration is the time derivative of velocity: \[ a(t) = \frac{dv(t)}{dt} = \frac{d^2x(t)}{dt^2} \]







Note


Working Backwards with Integrals: To go from acceleration to velocity, or from velocity to position, we use the inverse operation: integration.








flowchart LR
    X[Position $x(t)$] -- "$\frac{d}{dt}$" --> V[Velocity $v(t)$]
    V -- "$\frac{d}{dt}$" --> A[Acceleration $a(t)$]
    A -- "$\int dt$" --> V
    V -- "$\int dt$" --> X







This flowchart summarizes the derivative relationships we’ve already covered. Today, we’re focusing on the reverse direction: using integration. If differentiation tells us the rate of change, integration tells us the accumulation or total effect of that rate of change over time.

title: Physics
text:
Deriving Velocity from Acceleration
Given an acceleration function \(a(t)\), we can find the velocity function \(v(t)\) by integrating \(a(t)\) with respect to time:
\[ \frac{dv(t)}{dt} = a(t) \] \[ \int \frac{dv(t)}{dt} dt = \int a(t) dt \] \[ v(t) = \int a(t) dt + C_1 \]
Where \(C_1\) is the constant of integration, determined by the initial velocity.
\[ v(t) = \int a(t) dt + v_0 \]






Tip


Finding the Constant of Integration (\(C_1\)):
If \(v(0) = v_0\) (initial velocity at \(t=0\)), then \(v_0 = \int a(0) d(0) + C_1 \implies C_1 = v_0\).




This is the core idea: integration of acceleration yields velocity. The constant of integration, C1, is physically significant; it represents the velocity at time t=0, our initial velocity. So, if we know how acceleration changes over time, and we know the object’s starting velocity, we can determine its velocity at any future time.

title: Physics
text:
Deriving Position from Velocity
Similarly, given a velocity function \(v(t)\), we can find the position function \(x(t)\) by integrating \(v(t)\) with respect to time:
\[ \frac{dx(t)}{dt} = v(t) \] \[ \int \frac{dx(t)}{dt} dt = \int v(t) dt \] \[ x(t) = \int v(t) dt + C_2 \]
Where \(C_2\) is the constant of integration, determined by the initial position.
\[ x(t) = \int v(t) dt + x_0 \]






Tip


Finding the Constant of Integration (\(C_2\)):
If \(x(0) = x_0\) (initial position at \(t=0\)), then \(x_0 = \int v(0) d(0) + C_2 \implies C_2 = x_0\).




And here’s the second step: integration of velocity yields position. Again, the constant of integration, C2, is physically significant, representing the initial position. So, if we have the velocity function and the starting position, we can track the object’s position over time.

title: Physics
section: Deriving Constant Acceleration Equations with Calculus
text:
Deriving Constant Acceleration Equations with Calculus
Let’s use these integral forms to re-derive our familiar constant acceleration equations.
Assume \(a(t) = a\) (a constant).
Step 1: Find \(v(t)\)
\[ v(t) = \int a \, dt + C_1 = at + C_1 \]
At \(t=0\), \(v(0) = v_0 \implies C_1 = v_0\).
Thus: \[ \mathbf{v(t) = v_0 + at} \] (Our first kinematic equation!)
Step 2: Find \(x(t)\)
\[ x(t) = \int v(t) \, dt + C_2 = \int (v_0 + at) \, dt + C_2 \] \[ x(t) = v_0t + \frac{1}{2}at^2 + C_2 \]
At \(t=0\), \(x(0) = x_0 \implies C_2 = x_0\).
Thus: \[ \mathbf{x(t) = x_0 + v_0t + \frac{1}{2}at^2} \]
(Our second kinematic equation!)

This slide elegantly shows how the kinematic equations we’ve been using are simply special cases of these more general integral relationships, specifically when acceleration is constant. It reinforces the power of calculus in unifying these concepts. For engineers, understanding this derivation means you’re not just memorizing formulas, but understanding their fundamental origins.

title: Physics
text:
Example 3.17: Motion of a Motorboat
A motorboat is traveling at a constant velocity of \(5.0 \text{ m/s}\). It then starts to accelerate opposite to its motion to arrive at the dock. Its acceleration is given by: \[ a(t) = -\frac{1}{4}t \text{ m/s}^3 \]
Assume \(t=0\) when it starts accelerating.

What is the velocity function of the motorboat?
At what time does the velocity reach zero?
What is the position function of the motorboat?
What is the displacement of the motorboat from the time it begins to accelerate to when the velocity is zero?







Note


Initial conditions: \(v(0) = 5.0 \text{ m/s}\), assume \(x(0) = 0 \text{ m}\).




Here we have an acceleration that is not constant; it’s a function of time. This is where the integral approach really shines. This problem will walk us through finding the velocity and position functions and then using them to answer questions about the boat’s motion.

title: Physics
text:
Solution: Motorboat Motion (Part 1/3)
1. Velocity Function \(v(t)\)
Given \(a(t) = -\frac{1}{4}t\). Integrate to find \(v(t)\): \[ v(t) = \int a(t) dt = \int \left(-\frac{1}{4}t\right) dt + C_1 \] \[ v(t) = -\frac{1}{8}t^2 + C_1 \]
Use initial condition \(v(0) = 5.0 \text{ m/s}\): \[ 5.0 = -\frac{1}{8}(0)^2 + C_1 \implies C_1 = 5.0 \text{ m/s} \] Thus: \[ \mathbf{v(t) = 5.0 - \frac{1}{8}t^2 \text{ m/s}} \] (Units are simplified for clarity, assuming \(t\) in seconds).
2. Time When Velocity Reaches Zero
Set \(v(t) = 0\): \[ 0 = 5.0 - \frac{1}{8}t^2 \] \[ \frac{1}{8}t^2 = 5.0 \] \[ t^2 = 40 \] \[ t = \sqrt{40} \approx \mathbf{6.32 \text{ s}} \]

First, we perform the indefinite integral of the acceleration function. Then, we use the given initial velocity at t=0 to solve for the integration constant. With the velocity function in hand, finding when the velocity is zero is a simple algebraic step.

title: Physics
text:
Solution: Motorboat Motion (Part 2/3)
3. Position Function \(x(t)\)
Given \(v(t) = 5.0 - \frac{1}{8}t^2\). Integrate to find \(x(t)\): \[ x(t) = \int v(t) dt = \int \left(5.0 - \frac{1}{8}t^2\right) dt + C_2 \] \[ x(t) = 5.0t - \frac{1}{24}t^3 + C_2 \]
Use initial condition \(x(0) = 0 \text{ m}\) (boat starts accelerating from this reference point): \[ 0 = 5.0(0) - \frac{1}{24}(0)^3 + C_2 \implies C_2 = 0 \text{ m} \] Thus: \[ \mathbf{x(t) = 5.0t - \frac{1}{24}t^3 \text{ m}} \]

Following the same process, we integrate the velocity function we just found. Since we’re interested in displacement from the start of acceleration, we set the initial position to zero, making the integration constant also zero.

title: Physics
text:
Solution: Motorboat Motion (Part 3/3)
4. Displacement when Velocity is Zero
The velocity reaches zero at \(t \approx 6.32 \text{ s}\). Substitute this time into the position function \(x(t)\):
\[ x(6.32) = 5.0(6.32) - \frac{1}{24}(6.32)^3 \] \[ x(6.32) \approx 31.6 - \frac{1}{24}(252.88) \] \[ x(6.32) \approx 31.6 - 10.54 \] \[ \mathbf{x(6.32) \approx 21.06 \text{ m}} \] (The displacement is approximately \(21.1 \text{ m}\)).
Significance:

The acceleration is linear, leading to a quadratic velocity and cubic position function.
If the acceleration continued, the boat would reverse direction and eventually pass its starting point.
This method is crucial for systems with non-constant forces, common in advanced engineering dynamics.


Finally, to find the displacement, we simply evaluate the position function at the time when the velocity becomes zero. This type of analysis is common in engineering, for example, in designing control systems where acceleration might be modulated, or in modeling the trajectory of objects under complex forces. The graphs provided in the original text show that if the acceleration continued, the velocity would turn negative, and the boat would start moving backward, passing its original position.

section: Check Your Understanding: Particle Motion with Variable Acceleration
text:
Check Your Understanding: Particle Motion with Variable Acceleration
A particle starts from rest (\(v(0) = 0\)) and has an acceleration function: \[ a(t) = (5 - \frac{1}{2}t) \text{ m/s}^2 \]

What is the velocity function?
What is the position function?
When is the velocity zero (other than at \(t=0\))?

Assume \(x(0) = 0 \text{ m}\).

This problem is very similar to the motorboat example, but with a different acceleration function and initial conditions. Apply the same integral approach to find the velocity and position functions, and then determine when the velocity becomes zero. Remember your constants of integration!

title: Physics
section: Solution: Particle Motion with Variable Acceleration
text:
Solution: Particle Motion with Variable Acceleration
1. Velocity Function \(v(t)\)
Given \(a(t) = 5 - \frac{1}{2}t\). Integrate: \[ v(t) = \int \left(5 - \frac{1}{2}t\right) dt + C_1 = 5t - \frac{1}{4}t^2 + C_1 \] Given \(v(0) = 0\): \[ 0 = 5(0) - \frac{1}{4}(0)^2 + C_1 \implies C_1 = 0 \] Thus: \[ \mathbf{v(t) = 5t - \frac{1}{4}t^2 \text{ m/s}} \]
2. Position Function \(x(t)\)
Given \(v(t) = 5t - \frac{1}{4}t^2\). Integrate: \[ x(t) = \int \left(5t - \frac{1}{4}t^2\right) dt + C_2 = \frac{5}{2}t^2 - \frac{1}{12}t^3 + C_2 \] Given \(x(0) = 0\): \[ 0 = \frac{5}{2}(0)^2 - \frac{1}{12}(0)^3 + C_2 \implies C_2 = 0 \] Thus: \[ \mathbf{x(t) = \frac{5}{2}t^2 - \frac{1}{12}t^3 \text{ m}} \]

For the velocity and position functions, the integration steps are straightforward polynomial integrations. The initial conditions simplify the constants of integration to zero in this particular case.

title: Physics
section: Solution: Particle Motion with Variable Acceleration (Cont.)
text:
Solution: Particle Motion with Variable Acceleration (Cont.)
3. When is the velocity zero (other than at \(t=0\))?
Set \(v(t) = 0\): \[ 0 = 5t - \frac{1}{4}t^2 \] Factor out \(t\): \[ 0 = t \left(5 - \frac{1}{4}t\right) \] This gives two solutions: - \(t = 0 \text{ s}\) (initial condition) - $5 - t = 0 t = 5 t = $
The velocity is zero at \(t = \mathbf{20 \text{ s}}\).






Tip


Interpretation: The particle speeds up from \(t=0\) until \(t=20 \text{ s}\), then starts to slow down and eventually reverses direction if the acceleration function remains valid.




Solving for when velocity is zero again involves an algebraic step. The two solutions indicate that the particle starts at rest and then comes to rest again at 20 seconds. If the acceleration continued in the same manner, the particle would then begin to move in the opposite direction. This problem showcases how calculus enables us to fully characterize the motion of objects even under more complex, time-varying accelerations, which is critical for realistic engineering models.

title: Physics
text:
Key Takeaways

Calculus as a Tool: Integration allows us to find velocity from acceleration, and position from velocity, especially when acceleration is not constant.
Fundamental Relationships:

\(v(t) = \int a(t) dt + v_0\)
\(x(t) = \int v(t) dt + x_0\)

Initial Conditions: Constants of integration (\(v_0\) and \(x_0\)) are determined by the initial velocity and initial position, respectively.
Beyond Constant Acceleration: This integral method extends kinematics to scenarios with more complex, time-dependent accelerations, which are common in real-world engineering systems.


These key takeaways summarize the power and necessity of calculus in kinematics. While constant acceleration equations are useful, the integral approach provides the flexibility to analyze any acceleration profile. Understanding how to set up and solve these integrals, and how to use initial conditions to define the complete motion, is a fundamental skill for any engineer.

title: Physics
text:
Learning Objectives
By the end of this session, you will be able to:

Identify which equations of motion are to be used to solve for unknowns.
Use appropriate kinematic equations to solve problems involving single-body motion.
Apply kinematic equations to solve two-body pursuit problems.


Our main goals today are to understand and correctly apply the kinematic equations for constant acceleration. This involves recognizing the type of problem, identifying the knowns and unknowns, and then selecting the most efficient equations. We’ll start with single objects and then move to more complex scenarios where two objects interact.

title: Physics
text:
Simplified Notation & Constant Acceleration
To simplify our analysis, we make two key assumptions:

Initial Time is Zero (\(t_0 = 0\))

Elapsed time: \(\Delta t = t_f - t_0 \rightarrow t\)
Initial position: \(x_0\)
Initial velocity: \(v_0\)
Final position: \(x\)
Final velocity: \(v\)

Acceleration is Constant (\(a = \text{constant}\))

This is a crucial assumption for all equations we’ll derive.
Average acceleration (\(\bar{a}\)) is equal to instantaneous acceleration (\(a\)).








Important


Why constant acceleration? Many real-world situations have constant acceleration (e.g., free fall, controlled braking). Complex motions can often be broken into segments of constant acceleration.




The first simplification is purely for convenience, allowing us to drop subscripts for final values. The second, however, is fundamental to the kinematic equations we’re about to introduce. If acceleration is constant, it means the rate of change of velocity is steady. This allows us to use simple algebraic equations rather than calculus for solving problems. Many engineering scenarios, like a car braking or an object falling, can be modeled accurately with constant acceleration, at least over certain intervals.

title: Physics
text:
Displacement and Velocity Relationship
Starting from the definition of average velocity:
\[ \bar{v} = \frac{\Delta x}{\Delta t} \]
Using simplified notation:
\[ \bar{v} = \frac{x - x_0}{t} \]
Solving for final position \(x\):
\[ x = x_0 + \bar{v}t \]






Note


For Constant Acceleration: The average velocity is simply the average of initial and final velocities: \[ \bar{v} = \frac{v_0 + v}{2} \]










graph LR
    A["Definition of Average Velocity"] --> B["Simplify Notation ($t_0 = 0$)"]
    B --> C["Solve for Final Position $x$"]
    C --> D["Substitute $\bar{v}$ for Constant $a$"]
    D --> E["Equation: $x = x_0 + \frac{1}{2}(v_0 + v)t$"]










Velocity-versus-time graph with constant acceleration.


Figure 3.18 (a) illustrates that for constant acceleration, \(\bar{v}\) is the average of \(v_0\) and \(v\).


This slide lays the groundwork for our first set of kinematic equations. The definition of average velocity is always true. However, the ability to simply average the initial and final velocities (v0+v)/2 is only valid when acceleration is constant. The graph helps visualize this: with constant acceleration, the velocity-time graph is a straight line, and the average height of that line is just the midpoint between the initial and final heights.

title: Physics
text:
Kinematic Equation 1: Velocity-Time Relation
Deriving from the definition of acceleration:
\[ a = \frac{\Delta v}{\Delta t} \]
Using simplified notation (and constant \(a\)):
\[ a = \frac{v - v_0}{t} \]
Solving for final velocity \(v\):
\[ \mathbf{v = v_0 + at} \quad (\text{constant } a) \]






Tip


Key Insights:

Final velocity depends on initial velocity, acceleration, and time duration.
If \(a = 0\), then \(v = v_0\) (constant velocity).
If \(a\) is opposite to \(v_0\), the object slows down.





This is perhaps the most intuitive of the kinematic equations. It tells us directly how much our velocity changes if we accelerate at a constant rate for a certain amount of time. If you apply a constant force to an object (and therefore a constant acceleration), its velocity will change linearly with time. This equation is often used as a starting point for other derivations.

title: Physics
text:
Example 3.7: Airplane Braking
An airplane lands with an initial velocity of \(70.0 \text{ m/s}\) and then accelerates opposite to the motion at \(1.50 \text{ m/s}^2\) for \(40.0 \text{ s}\).
What is its final velocity?


Strategy:

Identify Knowns: \(v_0 = 70.0 \text{ m/s}\) (initial velocity) \(a = -1.50 \text{ m/s}^2\) (acceleration, negative because opposite to motion) \(t = 40.0 \text{ s}\) (time)
Identify Unknown: \(v\) (final velocity)
Choose Equation: The equation \(v = v_0 + at\) directly relates these quantities.





Airplane slowing down on a runway.


Figure 3.19: Acceleration is negative because its direction is opposite to velocity.


This problem is a direct application of the first kinematic equation. The crucial step here is correctly assigning the sign to acceleration. Since the airplane is slowing down while moving forward (which we’ll assume is the positive direction), its acceleration must be in the negative direction. This is a common point of error for students, so emphasize it.

title: Physics
text:
Solution: Airplane Braking
Calculation:
Given:
\(v_0 = 70.0 \text{ m/s}\)
\(a = -1.50 \text{ m/s}^2\)
\(t = 40.0 \text{ s}\)
Using \(v = v_0 + at\):
\[ v = 70.0 \text{ m/s} + (-1.50 \text{ m/s}^2)(40.0 \text{ s}) \] \[ v = 70.0 \text{ m/s} - 60.0 \text{ m/s} \] \[ \mathbf{v = 10.0 \text{ m/s}} \]
Significance:

The final velocity is positive, meaning the airplane is still moving in the original (positive) direction.
It has significantly slowed down, as expected from the negative acceleration.
This calculation is vital for runway length requirements and braking system design.


The final velocity of 10 m/s is positive, indicating the plane is still moving forward, but much slower. This result makes sense and can be validated by our intuition. Engineers use these types of calculations to determine safe landing distances, design braking systems, and assess passenger comfort during deceleration.

title: Physics
text:
Kinematic Equation 2: Position-Time Relation
We can combine:

Average velocity \(\bar{v} = v_0 + \frac{1}{2}at\) (derived from \(v = v_0 + at\) and \(\bar{v} = \frac{v_0+v}{2}\))
Displacement \(x = x_0 + \bar{v}t\)

Substitute (1) into (2):
\[ x = x_0 + \left( v_0 + \frac{1}{2}at \right)t \]
\[ \mathbf{x = x_0 + v_0t + \frac{1}{2}at^2} \quad (\text{constant } a) \]






Tip


Key Insights: - Displacement depends on the square of time when acceleration is present. - If \(a = 0\), then \(x = x_0 + v_0t\) (linear displacement for constant velocity).




This equation is very powerful as it directly relates position to time, initial velocity, and constant acceleration. The term 1/2at^2 shows that acceleration causes displacement to grow quadratically with time, meaning the distance covered increases rapidly as time passes when an object is accelerating. This is why a car needs significantly more distance to stop if its speed is doubled.

title: Physics
text:
Example 3.8: Dragster Displacement
A dragster accelerates from rest at \(26.0 \text{ m/s}^2\) for \(5.56 \text{ s}\).
How far does it travel in this time?


Strategy:

Identify Knowns:
\(x_0 = 0 \text{ m}\) (starting line)
\(v_0 = 0 \text{ m/s}\) (from rest)
\(a = 26.0 \text{ m/s}^2\)
\(t = 5.56 \text{ s}\)
Identify Unknown:
\(x\) (final position/displacement)
Choose Equation:
The equation \(x = x_0 + v_0t + \frac{1}{2}at^2\) is ideal.





Dragster accelerating from rest.


Figure 3.20: A dragster begins a race.


This example demonstrates how an object starting from rest covers a considerable distance when undergoing high, constant acceleration. Notice how we set x0 to zero; this is a common practice when we’re interested in the displacement from the starting point.

title: Physics
text:
Solution: Dragster Displacement
Calculation:
Given:
\(x_0 = 0 \text{ m}\)
\(v_0 = 0 \text{ m/s}\)
\(a = 26.0 \text{ m/s}^2\)
\(t = 5.56 \text{ s}\)
Using \(x = x_0 + v_0t + \frac{1}{2}at^2\):
Since \(x_0 = 0\) and \(v_0 = 0\), the equation simplifies to:
\(x = \frac{1}{2}at^2\)
Substitute values: \[ x = \frac{1}{2}(26.0 \text{ m/s}^2)(5.56 \text{ s})^2 \] \[ x = \frac{1}{2}(26.0)(30.9136) \text{ m} \] \[ \mathbf{x = 401.87 \text{ m}} \quad (\approx 402 \text{ m}) \]
Significance:

A significant distance covered in a short time due to high acceleration.
This distance is approximately a quarter-mile, the standard for drag racing, confirming the result’s reasonableness.


The calculation shows that a dragster covers about 400 meters, or a quarter-mile, in under 6 seconds, which is remarkably fast. This highlights the practical application of this kinematic equation in performance vehicle analysis and track design.

title: Physics
text:
Kinematic Equation 3: Velocity-Position Relation
This equation is especially useful when time is not known or not required.
Derivation:

Solve \(v = v_0 + at\) for \(t\): \(t = \frac{v - v_0}{a}\)
Substitute \(t\) and \(\bar{v} = \frac{v_0 + v}{2}\) into \(x = x_0 + \bar{v}t\)

\[ x - x_0 = \left( \frac{v_0 + v}{2} \right) \left( \frac{v - v_0}{a} \right) \]
\[ 2a(x - x_0) = (v_0 + v)(v - v_0) \]
\[ 2a(x - x_0) = v^2 - v_0^2 \]
\[ \mathbf{v^2 = v_0^2 + 2a(x - x_0)} \quad (\text{constant } a) \]

This equation is a powerful tool because it allows you to relate final velocity, initial velocity, acceleration, and displacement without needing to know the time. This often simplifies problems significantly. Notice how the derivation involves combining the previous two equations and eliminating time.

title: Physics
text:
Example 3.9: Dragster Final Velocity (Time-Independent)
Calculate the final velocity of the dragster from Example 3.8 (\(a = 26.0 \text{ m/s}^2\), starts from rest, travels \(402 \text{ m}\)) without using information about time.
Strategy:

Identify Knowns:
\(v_0 = 0 \text{ m/s}\) (from rest)
\(a = 26.0 \text{ m/s}^2\)
\(x - x_0 = 402 \text{ m}\) (displacement from Ex 3.8)
Identify Unknown:
\(v\) (final velocity)
Choose Equation:
The equation \(v^2 = v_0^2 + 2a(x - x_0)\) is perfectly suited as it does not require time.


This example specifically asks us to use the time-independent equation, which is a great way to reinforce its utility. We’re using the displacement we calculated earlier to find the final velocity, essentially working backward without needing the time value.

title: Physics
text:
Solution: Dragster Final Velocity (Time-Independent)
Calculation:
Given:
\(v_0 = 0 \text{ m/s}\)
\(a = 26.0 \text{ m/s}^2\)
\(x - x_0 = 402 \text{ m}\)
Using \(v^2 = v_0^2 + 2a(x - x_0)\):
\[ v^2 = (0 \text{ m/s})^2 + 2(26.0 \text{ m/s}^2)(402 \text{ m}) \]
\[ v^2 = 20904 \text{ m}^2/\text{s}^2 \]
\[ v = \sqrt{20904 \text{ m}^2/\text{s}^2} \]
\[ \mathbf{v = 144.58 \text{ m/s}} \quad (\approx 145 \text{ m/s}) \]
Significance:

A final velocity of \(145 \text{ m/s}\) is approximately \(522 \text{ km/h}\) or \(324 \text{ mi/h}\).
This equation highlights that final velocity depends on acceleration and the distance over which it acts.
For a fixed acceleration, stopping distance increases quadratically with initial velocity (e.g., doubling speed means quadrupling stopping distance). This is why speed limits near schools are so important.


The final velocity is extremely high, as expected for a dragster at the end of a quarter-mile. This result is also consistent with our previous calculations for the dragster. The significance emphasizes a critical safety aspect for engineers: stopping distances grow very rapidly with speed.

title: Physics
text:
Summary of Kinematic Equations (Constant \(a\))
These five equations are your toolbox for solving problems with constant acceleration.



Position from Average Velocity:
\[ x = x_0 + \bar{v}t \]
(Where \(\bar{v} = \frac{v_0 + v}{2}\) for constant \(a\))
Velocity-Time: \[ \mathbf{v = v_0 + at} \]
Position-Time: \[ \mathbf{x = x_0 + v_0t + \frac{1}{2}at^2} \]
Velocity-Position (Time-Independent): \[ \mathbf{v^2 = v_0^2 + 2a(x - x_0)} \]

This slide summarizes all the key equations. It’s like a toolkit. The flowchart visually represents how these equations link the initial and final states given constant acceleration. When solving problems, you’ll often have three knowns and want to find one of the two unknowns. By looking at the variables involved in each equation, you can quickly identify which one is most suitable for your problem.

title: Physics
text:
Challenge Problem: Car Braking Distance
On dry concrete, a car can accelerate opposite to the motion at a rate of \(7.00 \text{ m/s}^2\). On wet concrete, this rate is only \(5.00 \text{ m/s}^2\). The car is moving at \(30.0 \text{ m/s}\) (about \(110 \text{ km/h}\)).

Find the distance necessary to stop the car on dry concrete.
Find the distance necessary to stop the car on wet concrete.
Repeat both calculations, including a driver’s reaction time of \(0.500 \text{ s}\) to get their foot on the brake. (Assume velocity is constant during reaction time).







Tip


Problem-Solving Strategy: - Draw a sketch (like Figure 3.22 in the text). - List knowns and unknowns for each part of the problem. - Choose the most appropriate kinematic equation(s). - Pay attention to signs for acceleration (opposite to motion).




This problem is a comprehensive test of our understanding of constant acceleration. It breaks down into multiple parts, requires careful consideration of signs, and introduces the real-world factor of reaction time. Engineers regularly perform these calculations for road safety, traffic light timing, and vehicle design.

title: Physics
text:
Solution: Car Braking Distance (Part 1/3)
1. Stopping Distance on Dry Concrete
Knowns:
\(v_0 = 30.0 \text{ m/s}\)
\(v = 0 \text{ m/s}\) (car stops)
\(a = -7.00 \text{ m/s}^2\) (opposite to motion)
\(x_0 = 0 \text{ m}\)
Unknown: \(x\) (displacement \(\Delta x = x - x_0\))
Equation: \(v^2 = v_0^2 + 2a(x - x_0)\)
\[ 0^2 = (30.0 \text{ m/s})^2 + 2(-7.00 \text{ m/s}^2)(x - 0) \]
\[ 0 = 900 \text{ m}^2/\text{s}^2 - 14.0 \text{ m/s}^2 \cdot x \]
\[ 14.0 \text{ m/s}^2 \cdot x = 900 \text{ m}^2/\text{s}^2 \]
\[ x = \frac{900}{14.0} \text{ m} = \mathbf{64.3 \text{ m}} \]

For the first part, we apply the time-independent equation because time isn’t given or asked for. The negative sign for acceleration is crucial because the car is slowing down.

title: Physics
text:
Solution: Car Braking Distance (Part 2/3)
2. Stopping Distance on Wet Concrete
Knowns:
\(v_0 = 30.0 \text{ m/s}\)
\(v = 0 \text{ m/s}\)
\(a = -5.00 \text{ m/s}^2\)
\(x_0 = 0 \text{ m}\)
Unknown: \(x\)
Equation: \(v^2 = v_0^2 + 2a(x - x_0)\)
\[ 0^2 = (30.0 \text{ m/s})^2 + 2(-5.00 \text{ m/s}^2)(x - 0) \]
\[ 0 = 900 \text{ m}^2/\text{s}^2 - 10.0 \text{ m/s}^2 \cdot x \]
\[ 10.0 \text{ m/s}^2 \cdot x = 900 \text{ m}^2/\text{s}^2 \]
\[ x = \frac{900}{10.0} \text{ m} = \mathbf{90.0 \text{ m}} \]

As expected, the stopping distance on wet concrete is longer due to the reduced acceleration (less effective braking). This highlights the importance of road conditions for vehicle safety.

title: Physics
text:
Solution: Car Braking Distance (Part 3/3)
3. Total Displacement with Reaction Time (\(0.500 \text{ s}\))
The total distance is the sum of:

Displacement during reaction time (\(x_{\text{reaction}}\))
Braking distance (\(x_{\text{braking}}\))

a) Displacement during Reaction Time:
Assume constant velocity (\(a=0\)) during reaction time.
Knowns:
\(v = 30.0 \text{ m/s}\)
\(t = 0.500 \text{ s}\)
\(x_0 = 0 \text{ m}\)
Equation: \(x = x_0 + vt\)
\(x_{\text{reaction}} = 0 + (30.0 \text{ m/s})(0.500 \text{ s}) = \mathbf{15.0 \text{ m}}\)
b) Total Displacement

Dry Concrete: \(x_{\text{total, dry}} = x_{\text{braking, dry}} + x_{\text{reaction}}\) \(x_{\text{total, dry}} = 64.3 \text{ m} + 15.0 \text{ m} = \mathbf{79.3 \text{ m}}\)
Wet Concrete: \(x_{\text{total, wet}} = x_{\text{braking, wet}} + x_{\text{reaction}}\) \(x_{\text{total, wet}} = 90.0 \text{ m} + 15.0 \text{ m} = \mathbf{105.0 \text{ m}}\)







Warning


Reaction time adds significantly to the total stopping distance, demonstrating a critical factor in road safety and accident analysis.




This part adds a layer of realism. During reaction time, the car continues at its initial speed before braking begins. The 15 meters added by reaction time is substantial, making the total stopping distances much larger. This is a crucial consideration in traffic engineering and vehicle safety systems.

text:
Two-Body Pursuit Problems
These problems involve the motion of two interrelated objects.

The motions are “coupled” – the unknown depends on both objects.
Strategy:

Write separate kinematic equations for each object.
Identify a common parameter (e.g., time, position) that links their motions.
Solve the equations simultaneously for the unknown(s).









graph LR
    O1[Object 1 Equations] -- Common Parameter --> Solution
    O2[Object 2 Equations] -- Common Parameter --> Solution










Two-body pursuit scenario where car 2 has a constant velocity and car 1 is behind with a constant acceleration.


Figure 3.25: Car 1 (accelerating) catches Car 2 (constant velocity).


Two-body pursuit problems are a step up in complexity but are very common in engineering. Think about one car trying to overtake another, or a missile tracking a target. The key is to treat each object separately using the kinematic equations, and then find the link that connects their motions, usually a shared time or a shared position.

title: Physics
section: Challenge Problem: Cheetah Catching a Gazelle
text:
Challenge Problem: Cheetah Catching a Gazelle
A cheetah waits in hiding behind a bush. A gazelle runs past at a constant velocity of \(10 \text{ m/s}\). At the instant the gazelle passes the cheetah, the cheetah accelerates from rest at \(4 \text{ m/s}^2\) to catch the gazelle.

How long does it take the cheetah to catch the gazelle?
What is the displacement of the gazelle and cheetah when the catch occurs?







Tip


Common Parameter: At the moment the cheetah catches the gazelle, their positions (\(x\)) will be the same, and they will have been moving for the same amount of time (\(t\)) since the chase began.




This is a classic pursuit problem. We have two animals, one with constant velocity and one with constant acceleration. The key to solving it is recognizing that at the moment the cheetah catches the gazelle, they share the same position at the same time. We’ll set their position equations equal to each other.

title: Physics
text:
Solution: Cheetah and Gazelle (Part 1/2)
1. Time to Catch (\(t\))
Assume \(x_0 = 0\) for both animals at \(t=0\).
Gazelle’s motion (constant velocity):
\(v_G = 10 \text{ m/s}\)
\(x_G = x_{0G} + v_G t = 0 + 10t\)
\[ x_G = 10t \]
Cheetah’s motion (constant acceleration from rest):
\(v_{0C} = 0 \text{ m/s}\)
\(a_C = 4 \text{ m/s}^2\)
\(x_C = x_{0C} + v_{0C}t + \frac{1}{2}a_C t^2 = 0 + 0 \cdot t + \frac{1}{2}(4)t^2\)
\[ x_C = 2t^2 \]
When the cheetah catches the gazelle, \(x_C = x_G\):
\[ 2t^2 = 10t \]
\[ 2t^2 - 10t = 0 \]
\[ 2t(t - 5) = 0 \]
This yields two solutions: \(t = 0 \text{ s}\) (initial moment) and \(t = \mathbf{5 \text{ s}}\).
The cheetah catches the gazelle after \(\mathbf{5 \text{ seconds}}\).

By setting up separate equations for each animal and then equating their positions, we can solve for the common time. The t=0 solution simply means they were at the same place at the start of the chase. The t=5s is the meaningful solution for when the cheetah catches the gazelle.

title: Physics
text:
Solution: Cheetah and Gazelle (Part 2/2)
2. Displacement at Catching Moment
Using \(t = 5 \text{ s}\):
Displacement of Gazelle (\(x_G\)):
\[ x_G = 10t = 10 \text{ m/s} \times 5 \text{ s} = \mathbf{50 \text{ m}} \]
Displacement of Cheetah (\(x_C\)):
\[ x_C = 2t^2 = 2 \text{ m/s}^2 \times (5 \text{ s})^2 = 2 \times 25 \text{ m} = \mathbf{50 \text{ m}} \]
Conclusion:
Both animals travel a distance of \(\mathbf{50 \text{ m}}\) when the cheetah catches the gazelle.

As expected, both displacements are equal, confirming the cheetah indeed caught the gazelle at this distance. This type of problem-solving approach is invaluable in many engineering fields, from robotics to traffic control, where you need to analyze the relative motion of multiple systems.

Key Takeaways

Constant Acceleration: The kinematic equations are valid only when acceleration is constant.
Toolkit of Equations:

\(v = v_0 + at\)
\(x = x_0 + v_0t + \frac{1}{2}at^2\)
\(v^2 = v_0^2 + 2a(x - x_0)\)
\(x = x_0 + \frac{1}{2}(v_0 + v)t\)

Problem-Solving Strategy:

Establish a coordinate system.
Identify knowns and unknowns.
Select the appropriate equation(s).
Pay close attention to vector signs (direction).

Two-Body Problems: Write separate equations for each object and link them by a common variable (usually time or position) to solve simultaneously.


To wrap up, remember these critical points. The constant acceleration assumption is non-negotiable for these equations. Practice selecting the right equation for the given information. Always be mindful of the vector nature of velocity and acceleration through their signs. And finally, don’t be intimidated by two-body problems; just break them down into individual motions and find the common link. Mastering these concepts is fundamental for tackling more complex physics and engineering challenges. Thank you!

title: Physics
text:
Learning Objectives
By the end of this section, you will be able to:

Explain the difference between average velocity and instantaneous velocity.
Describe the difference between velocity and speed.
Calculate instantaneous velocity given a position function.
Calculate speed given instantaneous velocity.
Apply these concepts to analyze real-world engineering scenarios.


Today, we delve into the core concepts of instantaneous velocity and speed, crucial for analyzing dynamic systems in engineering. We’ll build on our understanding of average velocity and see how calculus allows us to precisely describe motion at any given moment.

title: Physics
text:
Revisiting Average Velocity
Recall that average velocity describes motion over an interval.
\[ \bar{v} = \frac{\Delta x}{\Delta t} = \frac{x(t_2) - x(t_1)}{t_2 - t_1} \]



Definition: Displacement divided by the time interval.
Vector Quantity: Has both magnitude and direction.
Overall Motion: Provides a general sense of movement over a period.








Note


Think of a road trip: your average velocity might be 60 km/h, but you drove faster and slower at various points.









Important


Average velocity tells us where an object ends up relative to its start, and how long it took. It doesn’t describe the journey’s details.





Average velocity is a good starting point, but in many engineering applications, we need a much more granular understanding of motion. For example, if we’re designing a system to avoid collisions, knowing the average velocity isn’t enough; we need to know the velocity at the precise moment of potential impact.

title: Physics
text:
Introduction to Instantaneous Velocity
Instantaneous velocity tells us how fast an object is moving at any single point in time.
It’s the limit of the average velocity as the time interval approaches zero.
\[ v(t) = \lim_{\Delta t \to 0} \frac{x(t + \Delta t) - x(t)}{\Delta t} \]
This is the fundamental definition of a derivative.
\[ v(t) = \frac{dx(t)}{dt} \]






Tip


In physics, “velocity” typically refers to instantaneous velocity unless specified as “average velocity.”




This is where calculus becomes indispensable in physics and engineering. By taking the derivative of the position function with respect to time, we can pinpoint the exact velocity at any given instant. This transition from average to instantaneous is a powerful conceptual leap.

title: Physics
text:
Instantaneous Velocity: Graphical Interpretation
On a position-versus-time graph, instantaneous velocity is the slope of the tangent line at a specific point.

Graph shows position plotted versus time





Note


At \(t_0\), the slope (and thus instantaneous velocity) is zero, indicating a momentary stop or reversal of direction.




This visual representation is crucial for understanding the concept. Imagine zooming in infinitely on a point on the x-t graph. The slope of that tiny segment is the instantaneous velocity. If the slope is positive, the object is moving in the positive direction. If negative, it’s moving in the negative direction. If zero, it’s momentarily at rest.

title: Physics
section: Velocity vs. Speed: A Crucial Distinction
text:
Velocity vs. Speed: A Crucial Distinction
In physics, velocity and speed are not interchangeable.


Velocity (\(v\))

Vector Quantity: Magnitude and Direction.
Describes rate of change of position.
Can be positive, negative, or zero.
Example: +5 m/s (moving east) or -5 m/s (moving west).


Speed (\(|v|\))

Scalar Quantity: Magnitude only.
Describes rate of change of distance traveled.
Always non-negative.
Calculated as the magnitude of instantaneous velocity.
Example: 5 m/s (regardless of direction).








Warning


Understanding this difference is critical for accurate problem-solving and system design in engineering. For instance, a robot might have zero average velocity if it returns to its starting point, but its average speed would reflect the total distance traveled.




This distinction is fundamental. While intuitively we might use them similarly, in physics and engineering, the direction component of velocity is often as important as its magnitude. Think about designing a vehicle: its speed limit is one thing, but its velocity vector determines its trajectory and collision potential.

title: Physics
text:
Calculating Instantaneous Velocity & Speed
When position \(x(t)\) is a function of time, we use differentiation.
For terms of the form \(At^n\):
\[ \frac{d(At^n)}{dt} = An t^{n-1} \]


Steps to find \(v(t)\):

Identify the position function, \(x(t)\).
Differentiate \(x(t)\) with respect to \(t\) using the power rule.
Substitute the specific time \(t\) into \(v(t)\) for instantaneous velocity.


Steps to find Speed:

First, find the instantaneous velocity \(v(t)\).
Calculate the magnitude of \(v(t)\): Speed \(= |v(t)|\).

If \(v(t)\) is 1D, this is simply the absolute value.




The power rule is our primary tool here. Remember that differentiation is a linear operation, meaning you can differentiate each term of a sum independently. Once you have the velocity, finding the speed is a straightforward step – just take the absolute value.

title: Physics
text:
Practical Application: Particle Motion
Consider a particle with position \(x(t) = (3.0 \text{ m/s})t + (0.5 \text{ m/s}^3)t^3\).


Part 1: Instantaneous Velocity

Find the instantaneous velocity \(v(t)\) at \(t = 2.0\) s.
Strategy: Differentiate \(x(t)\) to find \(v(t)\), then substitute \(t = 2.0\) s.


Part 2: Average Velocity

Calculate the average velocity between \(t = 1.0\) s and \(t = 3.0\) s.
Strategy: Find \(x(1.0 \text{ s})\) and \(x(3.0 \text{ s})\), then use the average velocity formula.



This problem highlights the difference between instantaneous and average velocity using a continuous function. Engineers frequently deal with such polynomial representations of motion, especially in trajectory analysis or control systems.

title: Physics
text:
Practical Application: Particle Motion (Solution)


Part 1: Instantaneous Velocity at \(t = 2.0\) s

Differentiate \(x(t)\): \(v(t) = \frac{d}{dt}[(3.0 \text{ m/s})t + (0.5 \text{ m/s}^3)t^3]\)
\(v(t) = (3.0 \text{ m/s}) + (1.5 \text{ m/s}^3)t^2\)
Substitute \(t = 2.0\) s: \(v(2.0 \text{ s}) = (3.0 \text{ m/s}) + (1.5 \text{ m/s}^3)(2.0 \text{ s})^2\)
\(v(2.0 \text{ s}) = 3.0 \text{ m/s} + (1.5 \text{ m/s}^3)(4.0 \text{ s}^2)\)
\(v(2.0 \text{ s}) = 3.0 \text{ m/s} + 6.0 \text{ m/s} = 9.0 \text{ m/s}\)


Part 2: Average Velocity (1.0 s to 3.0 s)

Calculate \(x(t)\) at \(t=1.0\) s and \(t=3.0\) s:
\(x(1.0 \text{ s}) = (3.0 \text{ m/s})(1.0 \text{ s}) + (0.5 \text{ m/s}^3)(1.0 \text{ s})^3 = 3.0 \text{ m} + 0.5 \text{ m} = 3.5 \text{ m}\)
\(x(3.0 \text{ s}) = (3.0 \text{ m/s})(3.0 \text{ s}) + (0.5 \text{ m/s}^3)(3.0 \text{ s})^3 = 9.0 \text{ m} + (0.5 \text{ m/s}^3)(27.0 \text{ s}^3) = 9.0 \text{ m} + 13.5 \text{ m} = 22.5 \text{ m}\)
Calculate average velocity:
\(\bar{v} = \frac{x(3.0 \text{ s}) - x(1.0 \text{ s})}{3.0 \text{ s} - 1.0 \text{ s}} = \frac{22.5 \text{ m} - 3.5 \text{ m}}{2.0 \text{ s}}\)
\(\bar{v} = \frac{19.0 \text{ m}}{2.0 \text{ s}} = 9.5 \text{ m/s}\)



Notice that the instantaneous velocity at 2.0 seconds (9.0 m/s) is close to, but not exactly equal to, the average velocity over the interval from 1.0 s to 3.0 s (9.5 m/s). This highlights that average velocity smooths out the details of motion.

title: Physics
text:
Engineering Challenge: Drone Trajectory Analysis
A drone’s horizontal position (in meters) is described by \(x(t) = 0.5t^3 - 4.5t^2 + 12t\), where \(t\) is in seconds.
Assume motion along a straight line.


Problem Questions:

What is the drone’s instantaneous velocity function, \(v(t)\)?
At what time(s) does the drone momentarily stop (i.e., its velocity is zero)?
What is the drone’s speed at \(t=1\) s and \(t=4\) s?
Describe the drone’s motion (direction and speed) at \(t=0.5\) s and \(t=3.5\) s.








Note


Hint for (2): Set \(v(t)=0\) and solve for \(t\). You’ll likely need to factor a quadratic equation.









Important


This problem mimics analyzing sensor data or predicting movement in drone control systems. Understanding these turning points and speeds is critical for navigation and collision avoidance.





This problem is designed to apply all the concepts we’ve discussed: differentiation for velocity, finding roots for stopping points, and calculating speed. It’s a typical scenario in robotics or autonomous vehicle engineering. Take a few minutes to work through it.

title: Physics
text:
Engineering Challenge: Drone Trajectory Analysis (Solution)
1. Instantaneous Velocity Function \(v(t)\):
\(x(t) = 0.5t^3 - 4.5t^2 + 12t\)
\(v(t) = \frac{dx}{dt} = \frac{d}{dt}(0.5t^3 - 4.5t^2 + 12t)\)
\(v(t) = 1.5t^2 - 9t + 12\)
2. Time(s) when the drone momentarily stops (\(v(t)=0\)):
\(1.5t^2 - 9t + 12 = 0\)
Divide by 1.5:
\(t^2 - 6t + 8 = 0\)
Factor:
\((t-2)(t-4) = 0\)
So, \(t = 2\) s and \(t = 4\) s.
3. Speed at \(t=1\) s and \(t=4\) s:

At \(t=1\) s:
\(v(1) = 1.5(1)^2 - 9(1) + 12 = 1.5 - 9 + 12 = 4.5\) m/s
Speed \(= |v(1)| = |4.5|\) m/s \(= 4.5\) m/s
At \(t=4\) s:
\(v(4) = 1.5(4)^2 - 9(4) + 12 = 1.5(16) - 36 + 12 = 24 - 36 + 12 = 0\) m/s
Speed \(= |v(4)| = |0|\) m/s \(= 0\) m/s
(Matches our finding from question 2!)


For question 2, solving the quadratic equation reveals two instances where the drone comes to a complete stop. These points are critical in trajectory planning for any moving system. For question 3, we see the speed calculation is straightforward once velocity is known.

title: Physics
section: Engineering Challenge: Drone Trajectory Analysis (Solution Cont.)
text:
Engineering Challenge: Drone Trajectory Analysis (Solution Cont.)
4. Describe drone’s motion at \(t=0.5\) s and \(t=3.5\) s:
Recall \(v(t) = 1.5t^2 - 9t + 12\).

At \(t=0.5\) s:
\(v(0.5) = 1.5(0.5)^2 - 9(0.5) + 12\)
\(v(0.5) = 1.5(0.25) - 4.5 + 12\)
\(v(0.5) = 0.375 - 4.5 + 12 = 7.875\) m/s
Motion: Drone is moving in the positive direction with a speed of 7.875 m/s.
At \(t=3.5\) s:
\(v(3.5) = 1.5(3.5)^2 - 9(3.5) + 12\)
\(v(3.5) = 1.5(12.25) - 31.5 + 12\)
\(v(3.5) = 18.375 - 31.5 + 12 = -1.125\) m/s
Motion: Drone is moving in the negative direction with a speed of 1.125 m/s.







Note


This analysis shows the drone starts moving in the positive direction, stops at \(t=2\)s, reverses direction to move negatively, stops again at \(t=4\)s, and then moves positively again. This type of detailed motion analysis is invaluable in engineering.




The final part of the problem demonstrates how the sign of velocity indicates direction. The drone changes direction at the points where its velocity is zero, as expected. This comprehensive understanding of motion is vital for designing robust and predictable engineering systems.

title: Physics
text:
Key Takeaways






Instantaneous Velocity vs. Average Velocity


Instantaneous velocity, \(v(t) = \frac{dx}{dt}\), describes motion at a specific instant, as the slope of the tangent to the position-time graph. Average velocity describes motion over an interval.









Velocity vs. Speed


Velocity is a vector (magnitude and direction), calculated by differentiating position. Speed is a scalar (magnitude only), calculated as the absolute value of velocity, \(|v(t)|\).









Calculus is Key


Understanding derivatives is fundamental to analyzing dynamic systems and predicting motion in engineering. The power rule, \(\frac{d(At^n)}{dt} = Ant^{n-1}\), is a crucial tool.




These three points summarize the core concepts from today’s lecture. Remember that the precision offered by instantaneous velocity and speed, enabled by calculus, is a cornerstone of advanced physics and engineering analysis.

By the end of this session, you will be able to:

These learning objectives will guide our discussion. By the end, you should have a solid grasp of these terms and be able to apply them to practical problems, as we’ll see with an engineering challenge later.

title: Physics I
text:
Introduction: Describing Motion
To analyze any moving system, we ask fundamental questions:



Where is the object?
Where is it going?
How fast is it moving?


These questions lead us to define:

Position
Displacement
Average Velocity








Note


In Engineering Physics, precise definitions are paramount. We need clear, unambiguous terms to build our models and ensure accurate analysis.




Whether you’re designing a high-speed train, programming an autonomous robot, or predicting the trajectory of a projectile, understanding these basics is essential. Kinematics is the branch of mechanics concerned with the motion of objects without reference to the forces that cause the motion.

title: Physics I
text:
Position (\(x\)) and Frame of Reference
Position (\(x\) or \(y\)) tells us where an object is at any particular time.



Defined relative to a frame of reference.
A frame of reference is an arbitrary set of axes, fixed to a chosen origin.
It provides a consistent baseline for measurement.

For example:

A rocket’s position relative to Earth.
A cyclist’s position relative to buildings along a road.
A passenger’s position relative to an airplane’s interior.





Cyclists in Vietnam


Figure 3.2: Cyclists in Vietnam. Their position can be described relative to buildings or a canal.


The choice of a frame of reference is critical and often simplifies problem-solving. For one-dimensional motion, we typically use the x-axis for horizontal motion and the y-axis for vertical motion. It’s arbitrary, but once chosen, we must stick to it consistently.

title: Physics I
text:
Displacement (\(\Delta x\))
Displacement is the change in an object’s position.



It implies an object has moved, or has been “displaced”.
Displacement is a vector quantity: it has both magnitude and direction.

Can be positive or negative, depending on the chosen positive direction.

Calculated as the difference between final and initial positions.

\[ \Delta x = x_f - x_0 \]
Where:

\(\Delta x\): displacement
\(x_f\): final position
\(x_0\): initial position







Important


The uppercase Greek letter \(\Delta\) (delta) always means “change in” whatever quantity follows it.







Professor pacing


Figure 3.3: A professor paces. Her displacement is \(+2.0\text{ m}\) to the right.


Displacement is not just how far something traveled, but also in what direction. If you walk 5 meters forward and 5 meters backward, your total displacement is zero, even though you walked a total of 10 meters. This distinction is crucial in physics and engineering for understanding net movement versus actual path taken.

title: Physics I
text:
Displacement - Multiple Movements
Often, motion involves a series of individual displacements.

Total Displacement is the sum of all individual displacements.

\[ \Delta x_{\text{Total}} = \sum \Delta x_i \]
Example: A professor moves \(2\text{ m}\) right, then \(4\text{ m}\) left.

First displacement: \(\Delta x_1 = +2\text{ m}\)
Second displacement: \(\Delta x_2 = -4\text{ m}\)
Total Displacement: \(\Delta x_{\text{Total}} = (+2\text{ m}) + (-4\text{ m}) = -2\text{ m}\)







Tip


The sign of displacement indicates its direction relative to the chosen positive axis. A negative \(\Delta x\) means the object is ultimately positioned in the negative direction from its starting point.




Even with multiple movements, total displacement only cares about the net change from start to finish. It doesn’t track the actual path taken between those points. This leads us to distinguish it from another important quantity: distance traveled.

title: Physics I
text:
Displacement vs. Distance Traveled
These two terms are often confused, but are fundamentally different.


Displacement (\(\Delta x\))

Vector quantity.
Change in position from the initial point to the final point.
Can be positive, negative, or zero.
Depends only on initial and final positions.
Formula: \(\Delta x = x_f - x_0\)


Distance Traveled (\(x_{\text{Total}}\))

Scalar quantity.
Total length of the entire path covered.
Always positive (or zero if no motion occurs).
Depends on the entire path taken.
Formula: \(x_{\text{Total}} = \sum |\Delta x_i|\)


Example (Professor):

Displacement: \(-2\text{ m}\) (The professor is \(2\text{ m}\) to the left of their starting point)
Distance Traveled: \(|+2\text{ m}| + |-4\text{ m}| = 2\text{ m} + 4\text{ m} = 6\text{ m}\) (The professor covered a total path length of \(6\text{ m}\))


Think about a lap on a race track. If you start and end at the same point, your displacement is zero. But you’ve certainly traveled a significant distance! This distinction is crucial for many engineering applications, such as calculating fuel efficiency (distance) versus precise navigation (displacement).

title: Physics I
text:
Introducing Time and Average Velocity
To fully describe motion, we must consider time (\(\Delta t\)).

Time allows us to describe how fast an object is moving.
The rate at which position changes with time is called velocity.

For basic analysis, we often use average velocity (\(\bar{v}\) or \(v_{\text{avg}}\)).






Note


Elapsed Time (\(\Delta t\)) is the time taken to travel between two points: \(\Delta t = t_f - t_0\).




We use ‘average’ velocity when the exact details of motion at every instant aren’t critical, or when the velocity might be changing. For example, a car doesn’t always move at a constant velocity. Later, we’ll delve into instantaneous velocity for more precise analysis.

title: Physics I
text:
Average Velocity (\(\bar{v}\))
Average Velocity is the total displacement divided by the elapsed time.
\[ \bar{v} = \frac{\text{Displacement}}{\text{Elapsed Time}} = \frac{\Delta x}{\Delta t} = \frac{x_f - x_0}{t_f - t_0} \]



Vector quantity: has magnitude and direction.
Can be positive, negative, or zero.
SI unit: meters per second (\(\text{m/s}\)).








Caution


Do not confuse average velocity with average speed. Average speed = \(\frac{\text{Total Distance Traveled}}{\text{Elapsed Time}}\).





The sign of average velocity directly corresponds to the sign of the total displacement. A positive average velocity means the object moved in the positive direction overall, regardless of any back-and-forth motion within that time interval. Average speed, being a scalar, will always be non-negative.

title: Physics I
text:
Conceptual Check
A train travels from Station A to Station B, a distance of 100 km east, in 1 hour.
It then travels from Station B to Station C, which is 50 km west of Station B, in 0.5 hours.
What is the train’s total displacement?



150 km east
50 km east
50 km west
150 km west








Tip


Remember, displacement is about the net change in position from start to end, and direction matters.





Take a moment to consider the directions and define your positive axis. Calculate each displacement vectorially, then sum them up. We’ll go over the solution on the next slide.

title: Physics I
text:
Conceptual Check - Solution
Let East be the positive direction (+x).

First displacement (Station A to B): \(\Delta x_1 = +100\text{ km}\)
Second displacement (Station B to C): \(\Delta x_2 = -50\text{ km}\)

Total Displacement:
\(\Delta x_{\text{Total}} = \Delta x_1 + \Delta x_2 = (+100\text{ km}) + (-50\text{ km}) = +50\text{ km}\)
The train’s total displacement is 50 km east.
Answer: B) 50 km east

Even though the train traveled a total distance of 150 km (100 km + 50 km), its net change in position from the starting point was only 50 km to the east. This is a clear demonstration of the difference between distance and displacement.

title: Physics I
Physics I
text:
Challenging Problem: Automated Drone Delivery
An engineering team is testing an autonomous delivery drone.
The drone starts from the base (position \(x=0\)).



It flies 0.5 km East to deliver Package 1, taking 9 minutes.
It realizes it missed a package and flies back to the base (West), taking another 9 minutes.
After loading, it flies 1.0 km East from the base to deliver Package 2, taking 15 minutes.
Finally, it flies 1.75 km West from its current position to scout a new delivery zone, taking 25 minutes, then rests.





Drone Delivery Timeline


Conceptual timeline of drone movements.

Your Task:

What is the drone’s total displacement when it stops to rest?
What is the magnitude of the final displacement?
What is the average velocity during its entire trip?
What is the total distance traveled?
Sketch a position versus time graph.


This problem integrates all the concepts we’ve discussed today in a practical engineering context. Take your time to break it down, carefully define your positive direction, and track each leg of the journey. We’ll solve it step-by-step on the following slides.

title: Physics I
text:
Problem-Solving Strategy
To tackle this multi-leg motion problem:

Define a positive direction: For instance, let East be +x.
Tabulate Data: Create a table tracking cumulative time and position for each segment.
Calculate Individual Displacements (\(\Delta x_i\)): For each leg of the journey.
Calculate Total Displacement (\(\Delta x_{\text{Total}}\)): Sum of all individual displacements.
Calculate Magnitude of Total Displacement: \(| \Delta x_{\text{Total}} |\), which is always positive.
Calculate Total Elapsed Time (\(\Delta t_{\text{Total}}\)): Sum of individual time intervals.
Calculate Average Velocity (\(\bar{v}\)): Total Displacement divided by Total Elapsed Time.
Calculate Total Distance Traveled (\(x_{\text{Total}}\)): Sum of the magnitudes of all individual displacements.
Visualize: Plot a position-time graph to better understand the motion.


A systematic approach is crucial in engineering. Breaking down complex problems into smaller, manageable steps reduces the chance of errors and clarifies your understanding of the physical processes involved.

title: Physics I
text:
Solution Part 1: Displacement Calculations
Let East be the positive direction (+). The drone starts at initial position (\(x_0\)) = 0 km at initial time (\(t_0\)) = 0 min.











Leg
Time \(t_i\) (min)
Position \(x_i\) (km)
Displacement \(\Delta x_i\) (km)

\(t_0=0\)
\(x_0=0\)
\(\Delta x_0=0\)


1
\(t_1=9\)
\(x_1=0.5\)
\(\Delta x_1 = x_1 - x_0 = 0.5\)


2
\(t_2=9+9=18\)
\(x_2=0\)
\(\Delta x_2 = x_2 - x_1 = -0.5\)


3
\(t_3=18+15=33\)
\(x_3=1.0\)
\(\Delta x_3 = x_3 - x_2 = 1.0\)


4
\(t_4=33+25=58\)

1. Total Displacement (\(\Delta x_{\text{Total}}\)):
Sum of individual displacements:
\(\Delta x_{\text{Total}} = 0.5 - 0.5 + 1.0 - 1.75\text{ km}\)
\(\Delta x_{\text{Total}} = -0.75\text{ km}\)
2. Magnitude of Final Displacement:
This is the absolute value of the total displacement.
\(| \Delta x_{\text{Total}} | = |-0.75\text{ km}| = 0.75\text{ km}\)


Notice how the positions are cumulative. The position at any given time is the sum of all preceding displacements from the origin. The final position directly gives us the total displacement when the starting point is zero. The negative sign for total displacement tells us the drone ended up West of its starting point.

title: Physics I
section: Solution Part 2: Average Velocity & Distance Traveled
text:
Solution Part 2: Average Velocity & Distance Traveled
3. Average Velocity (\(\bar{v}\)):

Total Displacement: \(\Delta x_{\text{Total}} = -0.75\text{ km}\) (from previous slide)
Total Elapsed Time: \(\Delta t_{\text{Total}} = 58\text{ min}\) (from the table)

\(\bar{v} = \frac{\Delta x_{\text{Total}}}{\Delta t_{\text{Total}}} = \frac{-0.75\text{ km}}{58\text{ min}}\)
\(\bar{v} \approx -0.013\text{ km/min}\)
4. Total Distance Traveled (\(x_{\text{Total}}\)):
Sum of the magnitudes of individual displacements:
\(x_{\text{Total}} = |\Delta x_1| + |\Delta x_2| + |\Delta x_3| + |\Delta x_4|\)
\(x_{\text{Total}} = |0.5\text{ km}| + |-0.5\text{ km}| + |1.0\text{ km}| + |-1.75\text{ km}|\)
\(x_{\text{Total}} = 0.5 + 0.5 + 1.0 + 1.75\text{ km}\)
\(x_{\text{Total}} = 3.75\text{ km}\)

The negative average velocity indicates that, on average, the drone moved in the negative (West) direction relative to its starting point over the entire trip. Its total path length, however, was 3.75 km. This highlights how an inefficient path can significantly increase distance traveled while having a small net displacement.

title: Physics I
text:
Solution Part 3: Position-Time Graph
5. Position vs. Time Graph:

Position vs. time graph for Jill’s movements (now drone)
The slope of the position-time graph at any point represents the instantaneous velocity.
For each segment, a constant slope indicates constant velocity during that time interval.
A positive slope means positive velocity (East direction).
A negative slope means negative velocity (West direction).
The average velocity for the entire trip is the slope of the straight line connecting the initial point (0 min, 0 km) and the final point (58 min, -0.75 km).


This graph is a powerful visualization tool for engineers. It allows us to quickly assess the nature of motion, identify periods of constant velocity, changes in direction, and overall trends. The steeper the slope, the greater the speed of the drone.

title: Physics I
text:
Engineering Significance of Results
Understanding these kinematic values is critical for drone system design and mission planning:

Total Displacement (\(\mathbf{-0.75\text{ km}}\)):

Indicates the drone’s final position is \(0.75\text{ km}\) West of its starting base.
Essential for navigation systems to guide the drone back to the correct landing spot or to its precise final destination.

Average Velocity (\(\mathbf{-0.013\text{ km/min}}\)):

Represents the effective “straight-line” velocity from the start to the end point over the entire mission duration.
Useful for high-level mission planning and estimating total mission duration if direct flight were possible, but doesn’t reflect the actual path efficiency.

Total Distance Traveled (\(\mathbf{3.75\text{ km}}\)):

Crucial for battery consumption calculations and range estimation.
A drone flying \(3.75\text{ km}\) consumes significantly more energy than one flying a direct \(0.75\text{ km}\) displacement, impacting operational costs and flight endurance.








Warning


For autonomous systems, accurately distinguishing between displacement and distance traveled is paramount for precise navigation, optimal path planning, and efficient resource (e.g., energy) management.




Imagine if the drone’s navigation system only considered displacement. It might think it’s close to its target when it has actually done a lot of unnecessary flying, which would drain its battery much faster than anticipated. Distance traveled dictates the actual work done and energy expenditure.

title: Physics I
text:
Check Your Understanding: Robotic Rover
A robotic rover exploring Mars travels 3 km West from its landing site, then turns around and travels 2 km East.


(a) What is the rover’s total displacement? (b) What is the total distance traveled? (c) What is the magnitude of its displacement?




Mars Rover Movement


Conceptual timeline of rover movements.


This is a very common scenario in planetary exploration where a rover might make multiple movements to navigate around obstacles or to investigate different sites. Apply the principles we’ve just covered to analyze its motion. For consistency, let’s assume East is the positive direction for our calculations.

title: Physics I
text:
Solution to Check Your Understanding
Let East be positive (+x), so West is negative (-x).

First movement: \(\Delta x_1 = -3\text{ km}\) (3 km West)
Second movement: \(\Delta x_2 = +2\text{ km}\) (2 km East)

(a) Total Displacement (\(\Delta x_{\text{Total}}\)):
\(\Delta x_{\text{Total}} = \Delta x_1 + \Delta x_2 = (-3\text{ km}) + (+2\text{ km}) = -1\text{ km}\)
The rover’s total displacement is 1 km West from its landing site.
(b) Total Distance Traveled (\(x_{\text{Total}}\)):
\(x_{\text{Total}} = |\Delta x_1| + |\Delta x_2| = |-3\text{ km}| + |+2\text{ km}| = 3\text{ km} + 2\text{ km} = 5\text{ km}\)
The total distance traveled is 5 km.
(c) Magnitude of Displacement:
\(| \Delta x_{\text{Total}} | = |-1\text{ km}| = 1\text{ km}\)
The magnitude of its displacement is 1 km.

This problem clearly highlights the critical distinction between displacement and distance. While the rover is effectively 1 km west of its starting point, its internal odometers would show 5 km traveled. This ‘travel distance’ directly impacts maintenance schedules, energy consumption, and the overall longevity of the rover’s mission.

title: Physics I
text:
Key Takeaways


1. Position is relative: Always defined with respect to a chosen frame of reference.
2. Displacement (\(\Delta x\)): - A vector quantity representing the net change in position from start to finish. - Calculated as: \(\Delta x = x_f - x_0\) - Can be positive, negative, or zero.
3. Distance Traveled (\(x_{\text{Total}}\)): - A scalar quantity representing the total length of the actual path taken. - Calculated as: \(x_{\text{Total}} = \sum |\Delta x_i|\) - Always positive.

4. Average Velocity (\(\bar{v}\)): - A vector quantity representing the rate of displacement over time. - Calculated as: \(\bar{v} = \frac{\Delta x}{\Delta t}\) - Can be positive, negative, or zero. - Distinct from average speed, which uses total distance.
5. Engineering Relevance: These concepts are foundational for: - Navigation systems (e.g., GPS, autonomous vehicles) - Trajectory planning and control (e.g., rockets, robotics) - Performance analysis of vehicles and machines - Resource management (e.g., fuel/energy consumption, wear-and-tear)







Important


Always pay attention to both magnitude and direction when dealing with vector quantities like displacement and velocity! This distinction is crucial for accurate engineering analysis.




These five points are the core knowledge you should retain from this lecture. Mastering them will enable you to effectively analyze and design systems involving motion, which is a cornerstone of many engineering disciplines. Thank you!

title: Physics
section: Understanding Acceleration: From Theory to Application
text:
Understanding Acceleration: From Theory to Application

Welcome everyone to today’s session on acceleration! We’re going to dive into a fundamental concept in physics that’s crucial for any engineering discipline. We’ll move beyond just “speeding up” and understand acceleration in a precise, quantitative way. Our goal is to connect the theoretical definitions with practical examples you might encounter in engineering.

title: Physics
text:
Learning Objectives
By the end of this session, you will be able to:

Calculate the average acceleration between two points in time.
Calculate the instantaneous acceleration given the functional form of velocity.
Explain the vector nature of instantaneous acceleration and velocity.
Distinguish between average acceleration and instantaneous acceleration.
Find instantaneous acceleration at a specified time on a graph of velocity versus time.


These learning objectives will guide our discussion today. We’ll start with average acceleration, then move to the more complex instantaneous acceleration, emphasizing the vector nature of these quantities. We’ll also look at how to interpret acceleration from graphs, which is a key skill.

title: Physics
text:
What is Acceleration?
Beyond “Speeding Up”
Acceleration is the rate at which velocity changes.

It’s not just about changing speed.
It’s also about changing direction.







Note


Why is it important for Engineers? Understanding acceleration is vital for designing safe vehicles, analyzing structural loads, optimizing manufacturing processes, and even predicting celestial mechanics in aerospace engineering.

title: Physics
text:
Average Acceleration: The Definition
Average acceleration (\(\bar{a}\)) is the total change in velocity (\(\Delta v\)) over a total change in time (\(\Delta t\)).
\[
\bar{a} = \frac{\Delta v}{\Delta t} = \frac{v_f - v_0}{t_f - t_0}
\]

\(\bar{a}\): average acceleration
\(v_f\): final velocity
\(v_0\): initial velocity
\(t_f\): final time
\(t_0\): initial time







Important


SI Units: meters per second squared (\(\text{m/s}^2\)) This means how many meters per second the velocity changes every second.




The formula for average acceleration is straightforward. It’s simply the change in velocity divided by the time interval over which that change occurred. Remember that velocity is a vector, so a change in velocity can mean a change in speed, a change in direction, or both. The units of m/s² might seem a bit abstract at first, but think of it as (m/s)/s, reinforcing the idea of “change in velocity per second”.

title: Physics
text:
Acceleration as a Vector
Acceleration is a vector quantity.

It has both magnitude and direction.
Its direction is the same as the direction of the change in velocity (\(\Delta v\)).



Change in Velocity (\(\Delta v\)):

Can be a change in speed (magnitude).
Can be a change in direction.
Can be both.







graph LR
    A[Initial Velocity $v_0$] --> B[Final Velocity $v_f$]
    B -- "$v_f - v_0$" --> C[Change in Velocity $\Delta v$]
    C --> D[Acceleration $a$]
  
    subgraph Vector Components
        A -- Magnitude & Direction --> v0_vec["Vector $\vec{v}_0$"]
        B -- Magnitude & Direction --> vf_vec["Vector $\vec{v}_f$"]
        D -- Magnitude & Direction --> a_vec["Vector $\vec{a}$"]
    end








This diagram illustrates how acceleration is fundamentally linked to the change in velocity. Since acceleration inherits its direction from the change in velocity, it is also a vector. This is a critical point: if an object is moving in a circle at a constant speed, its velocity is constantly changing direction, and therefore it is accelerating.

title: Physics
text:
Avoiding “Deceleration”
The term “deceleration” can be misleading.

It’s not a vector.
It implies only slowing down.

Instead, we describe acceleration using its sign in a chosen coordinate system.





A subway train accelerates opposite to the motion as it comes into a station.



If motion is in the positive direction and the train is slowing down, its acceleration is negative.
If motion is in the negative direction and the train is speeding up, its acceleration is also negative.






Tip


Always refer to acceleration as a vector with a specific direction (positive or negative) relative to your coordinate system.





Let’s look at the example of a subway train braking. If we define “forward” as the positive direction, then as the train slows down, its acceleration is in the opposite direction of its velocity, meaning it has a negative acceleration. This is often called deceleration, but it’s more accurate and less confusing to simply say “negative acceleration” because acceleration is a vector. This avoids confusion when an object speeds up in the negative direction, which also constitutes a negative acceleration.

title: Physics
text:
Example: Racehorse Acceleration
A racehorse coming out of the gate accelerates from rest to a velocity of 15.0 m/s due west in 1.80 s.
What is its average acceleration?





Racehorses accelerating out of the gate.



Strategy

Sketch & Coordinate System: Assign east as positive, west as negative.
Identify Knowns: \(v_0 = 0 \text{ m/s}\) (rest) \(v_f = -15.0 \text{ m/s}\) (west is negative) \(\Delta t = 1.80 \text{ s}\)
Apply Formula: \(\bar{a} = \frac{v_f - v_0}{\Delta t}\)



Here’s a classic kinematics problem. The first step is crucial: setting up a coordinate system. By defining east as positive, west becomes negative, which means the final velocity of the horse is -15 m/s. This allows us to correctly use the formula for average acceleration.

title: Physics
text:
Solution: Racehorse Acceleration
Calculation
Given:
\(v_0 = 0 \text{ m/s}\)
\(v_f = -15.0 \text{ m/s}\)
\(\Delta t = 1.80 \text{ s}\)
Change in velocity:
\(\Delta v = v_f - v_0 = -15.0 \text{ m/s} - 0 \text{ m/s} = -15.0 \text{ m/s}\)
Average acceleration: \[
\bar{a} = \frac{\Delta v}{\Delta t} = \frac{-15.0 \text{ m/s}}{1.80 \text{ s}} = -8.33 \text{ m/s}^2
\]
Significance

The negative sign indicates the acceleration is due west.
The horse’s velocity increases by 8.33 m/s due west each second.
This is an average acceleration; the actual acceleration might vary during the 1.80 s.


The calculation is straightforward application of the formula. The negative sign for acceleration is not a mistake; it clearly tells us the direction of the acceleration. In this case, it means the horse is accelerating in the west direction. This magnitude of acceleration is quite significant and highlights the power a racehorse exerts from the starting gate.

title: Physics
text:
Check Your Understanding: Proton Accelerator
Protons in a linear accelerator are accelerated from rest to \(2.0 \times 10^7 \text{ m/s}\) in \(10^{-4} \text{ s}\).
What is the average acceleration of the protons?






Tip


Assume the direction of motion is positive.




Take a moment to solve this problem on your own. It’s similar to the racehorse example, but with different magnitudes and a simplified direction. Use the same average acceleration formula.

title: Physics
text:
Solution: Proton Accelerator
Calculation
Given:
\(v_0 = 0 \text{ m/s}\) (from rest)
\(v_f = 2.0 \times 10^7 \text{ m/s}\)
\(\Delta t = 10^{-4} \text{ s}\)
Average acceleration: \[
\bar{a} = \frac{v_f - v_0}{\Delta t} = \frac{2.0 \times 10^7 \text{ m/s} - 0 \text{ m/s}}{10^{-4} \text{ s}}
\]
\[
\bar{a} = \frac{2.0 \times 10^7 \text{ m/s}}{10^{-4} \text{ s}} = 2.0 \times 10^{11} \text{ m/s}^2
\]
Interpretation
This is an incredibly large acceleration, characteristic of particle accelerators, showing how quickly subatomic particles can gain immense speeds.

The result, \(2.0 \times 10^{11} \text{ m/s}^2\), is enormous! This demonstrates the kind of extreme accelerations achieved in advanced engineering and physics applications like linear particle accelerators, where particles are brought to relativistic speeds.

title: Physics
text:
Instantaneous Acceleration
Instantaneous acceleration (\(a\)) is the acceleration at a specific instant in time.

It’s the limit of the average acceleration as the time interval (\(\Delta t\)) approaches zero.

\[
a(t) = \lim_{\Delta t \to 0} \frac{\Delta v}{\Delta t} = \frac{dv(t)}{dt}
\]






Note


Instantaneous acceleration is the derivative of the velocity function with respect to time. \[
a(t) = \frac{d}{dt} v(t)
\]

title: Physics
text:
Graphical Interpretation
On a velocity-versus-time (\(v-t\)) graph:

Average acceleration is the slope of the secant line connecting two points.
Instantaneous acceleration is the slope of the tangent line at a specific point in time.








graph TD
    A["Velocity Function $v(t)$"] --> B{Graph $v$ vs. $t$}
    B --> C[Choose Time $t_0$]
    C --> D[Draw Tangent Line at $t_0$]
    D --> E[Slope of Tangent Line]
    E --> F["Instantaneous Acceleration $a(t_0)$"]










In a graph of velocity versus time, instantaneous acceleration is the slope of the tangent line.




Just as instantaneous velocity is the slope of the position-time graph, instantaneous acceleration is the slope of the velocity-time graph. This graphical interpretation is very powerful. When the velocity curve is steepest, acceleration is greatest. When the velocity curve is flat (zero slope), acceleration is zero, which means the velocity is momentarily constant or at a maximum/minimum.

title: Physics
text:
Example: Calculating Instantaneous Acceleration
A particle’s velocity is given by \(v(t) = (20 \text{ m/s}^2)t - (5 \text{ m/s}^3)t^2\).

Find the functional form of the acceleration \(a(t)\).
Find the instantaneous velocity at \(t = 1, 2, 3, \text{ and } 5 \text{ s}\).
Find the instantaneous acceleration at \(t = 1, 2, 3, \text{ and } 5 \text{ s}\).
Interpret the results of (c) in terms of the directions of the acceleration and velocity vectors.


This example requires us to use calculus, specifically differentiation. For part 4, we’ll compare the signs of velocity and acceleration to understand if the particle is speeding up or slowing down, and in which direction.

title: Physics
text:
Solution: Instantaneous Acceleration (Part 1/2)
1. Functional form of acceleration
\[
a(t) = \frac{dv(t)}{dt} = \frac{d}{dt} \left( (20 \text{ m/s}^2)t - (5 \text{ m/s}^3)t^2 \right)
\] \[
a(t) = (20 \text{ m/s}^2) - (10 \text{ m/s}^3)t
\]
2. Instantaneous velocity at specific times

\(v(1 \text{ s}) = 20(1) - 5(1)^2 = 15 \text{ m/s}\)
\(v(2 \text{ s}) = 20(2) - 5(2)^2 = 40 - 20 = 20 \text{ m/s}\)
\(v(3 \text{ s}) = 20(3) - 5(3)^2 = 60 - 45 = 15 \text{ m/s}\)
\(v(5 \text{ s}) = 20(5) - 5(5)^2 = 100 - 125 = -25 \text{ m/s}\)


First, we differentiate the velocity function to get the acceleration function. Then, we simply substitute the given time values into both the velocity and acceleration functions. Notice how the velocity changes from positive to negative, indicating a change in direction.

title: Physics
text:
Solution: Instantaneous Acceleration (Part 2/2)
3. Instantaneous acceleration at specific times

\(a(1 \text{ s}) = 20 - 10(1) = 10 \text{ m/s}^2\)
\(a(2 \text{ s}) = 20 - 10(2) = 0 \text{ m/s}^2\)
\(a(3 \text{ s}) = 20 - 10(3) = -10 \text{ m/s}^2\)
\(a(5 \text{ s}) = 20 - 10(5) = -30 \text{ m/s}^2\)

4. Interpretation

t = 1 s: \(v = +15 \text{ m/s}\), \(a = +10 \text{ m/s}^2\). Both positive. Particle is speeding up in the positive direction.
t = 2 s: \(v = +20 \text{ m/s}\) (maximum velocity), \(a = 0 \text{ m/s}^2\). Acceleration is zero when velocity is maximum or minimum.
t = 3 s: \(v = +15 \text{ m/s}\), \(a = -10 \text{ m/s}^2\). Velocity positive, acceleration negative. Particle is slowing down (still moving positive).
t = 5 s: \(v = -25 \text{ m/s}\), \(a = -30 \text{ m/s}^2\). Both negative. Particle has reversed direction and is speeding up in the negative direction.


The interpretation of the signs of velocity and acceleration is critical. If their signs are the same, the object is speeding up. If their signs are opposite, the object is slowing down. At t=2s, acceleration is zero, indicating that the particle has reached its maximum positive velocity before starting to slow down and eventually reverse direction.

title: Physics
text:
Check Your Understanding: Airplane Landing
An airplane lands on a runway, initially traveling east.
Describe its acceleration as it slows down to a stop.






Note


Consider the direction of motion and the direction of the force causing it to slow down.




Think about setting up a coordinate system. If the airplane is traveling east, what direction is that? And if it’s slowing down, what direction must its acceleration be?

title: Physics
text:
Solution: Airplane Landing
Description

Coordinate System: Let’s define East as the positive direction. Therefore, the initial velocity of the airplane is positive.
Slowing Down: For the airplane to slow down while moving in the positive (eastward) direction, its acceleration must be opposite to its velocity.
Conclusion: The airplane experiences a negative acceleration (or acceleration directed westward) as it slows down.


This scenario perfectly illustrates why using “negative acceleration” is clearer than “deceleration.” The airplane’s velocity is positive (east), but to slow down, its acceleration must be negative (west). This negative acceleration will eventually bring the plane to a stop.
